properties.name: Candy
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   The Sears candy counter was just about here.

properties.name: Dairy Cows
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg  This is where the MacArthur Dairy was located, surrounded by cow pastures.

properties.name: Drive-In
properties.description: Posted by MhalbergThe old Broward Drive-In Theater was located on this site. I\'m not sure what year it closed. I do remember seeing "Casper the Friendly Ghost" here though. My brother and I liked watching movies at the drive-in because we could wear our pajamas and bring home-made popcorn.

properties.name: Drive-In Market
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   We came here for the sherbet, milk and ice-cream.

properties.name: Football Field
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg    This is the approximate location of the 50 yard line on the field where my brother and I played our little league football games. You could often hear the loudspeaker at the King car dealership next door paging employees on the lot.

properties.name: Graduation
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg  This is where I graduated from Dillard High School in 1976.

properties.name: Grandmother's
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   My Grandmother moved here after my Grandfather died.

properties.name: Great Burgers
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   My Grandmother used to take me here for burgers, We\'d sit at the counter drinking Birch Beer watching the cook grill our tiny burgers and onions and buns.

properties.name: Hiding Place
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg  Mr. Franks, our Vice-Principle, spotted us off-campus when we were supposed to be in study hall. We ran and to our suprise, he chased us. We sought refuge in the bushes behind the store, but he was soon upon us, telling us it was the most excitement he had had all day. This store is where I obtained my first copy of National Lampoon magazine (The "cheating" issue as I recall) which arguably influenced my comic sensibility of today.

properties.name: High School
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   Spent my first two years of high school here, 1972-1974.

properties.name: Lauderdale Manors
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   This was the house I grew up in. The center of my universe from late 1958 to 1976.

properties.name: Lauderdale Villa Trees
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   Lots of action took place in and around these trees. A great place to hang out and do things you weren\'t supposed to be doing : )

properties.name: Learned To Drive
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg  This is where my father turned me loose behind the wheel of the family car. Life was never the same.

properties.name: Library
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   I spent many an evening here with my father, usually leaving with my limit of books.

properties.name: McDonalds or Heavenly Subs?
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   Where I learned to appreciate the meatball sub, or alternatively, the McDonalds we would stop at on Thursdays (payday) on the way home from little league football practice.

properties.name: Old Airport
properties.description: Posted by MhalbergIn the 1960\'s my father would bring me to this small airport to check out the activity. I remember that next to the airport office sat a huge ficus tree which may still be there. In later years after the airport was closed this undeveloped area was our natural playground. We explored these woods and fought battles with slingshots and bb guns. An old man farmed a small plot of land and grew egglpnt and cucumber. He had an old donkey and legend had it that he possessed a shotgun loaded with rock salt and was not afraid to send a few rounds fly in the direction of errent youths messing with his produce.

properties.name: Old Motel
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   At one time this building was the Wm. Talley House, a motel along Federal Highway with a distinctive sign visible from the park where we practiced football and baseball.

properties.name: Paul's Magic and Fun Shop
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg    I spent many hours of my youth hanging out in this magic shop. Every young boy should have a magic shop to hang out in!

properties.name: Piggly Wiggly
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   My grandmother did her grocery shopping here in the 60\'s. Then it became a "Peaches Records and Tapes" store in the 70\'s. Not sure what\'s there now.

properties.name: Pines and Palmettos
properties.description: Posted by MhalbergPrior to I-95 being extended from Davie Blvd., this area was covered with pine trees and an undergrowth of palmetto. It was another great area to explore in the 1960\'s. After the Interstate was first paved it seems it took several months before it actually opened to traffic. During this time we used the fresh asphalt as our private expressway, riding our bikes on fishing expeditions to the North.

properties.name: Pony Ride
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   This is the approximate location of a pony ride my parents used to take my brother and I in the 60\'s. The Thunderbird Swap-Shop is there now.

properties.name: Pool
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg   This is where the Lauderdale Manors Pool used to be located. I\'m not sure when it was relocated.

properties.name: Sky Diving
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg Back in the 1960\'s this was an area covered with sugar sand, crab grass, and moss-draped cypress trees. The area served a dual purpose; There was a flag-encircled ring where gas-engine model airplane enthusiasts put their aircraft through their paces. There were acrobatic displays and dog-fights between streamer towing flying wings. It was also where sky divers landed on Sundays. I recall overhearing a recently landed skydiver as he gathered his chute describe to another how his shoulder banged into a wing when departing the aircraft.

properties.name: Snacks, Haircuts and Guns
properties.description: Posted by MhalbergThis small strip-mall contained a 7-11, a barbershop where Frank gave me crewcuts and bubble-gum (I still remember the combined smell of bubble-gum and talc), and a gun shop where my Dad bought me my first air rifle.

properties.name: Trailer Park
properties.description: Posted by Mhalberg    This is the approximate location of the trailer park where my grandparents lived in an Airstream in the early 60\'s

properties.name: Two Incidents
properties.description: Posted by MhalbergTwo auto-related accidents occured on or near this corner. The first was when I was still in grade-school or middle-school. My best friend Walley, who lived in this corner house, was away on vacation with his family. While they were away a car collided with a mail truck and then ran into the fire hydrant on the corner. Water shot into the air and then ran down the street, beckoning the neighborhood children to the scene. I watched as a portion of Walley\'s front yard fell into a swirling whirlpool and wondered if he was having a good time in Bermuda. The second accident occured one day as my friend Jim drove his freshly painted Renault around the corner. The car slid across the gravel-covered asphalt and into the soft dirt on the side, which abrubtly stopped the car\'s momentum causing it to roll over on it\'s side in the middle of the street. I laughed so hard I wet my pants.
